title: 112_hr2557
content: Establishment of a Tick-Borne Diseases Advisory Committee. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will establish the Tick-Borne Diseases Advisory Committee to advise on interagency coordination and communication efforts to address tick-borne diseases. The Tick-Borne Diseases Advisory Committee will ensure interagency coordination, communication, and collaboration with other organizations to address tick-borne diseases. They will also represent a broad spectrum of scientific viewpoints in public health policy decisions and advise relevant Federal agencies on priorities. The Tick-Borne Diseases Advisory Committee will ensure a broad spectrum of scientific viewpoints in public health policy decisions and advise Federal agencies on priorities related to Lyme and tick-borne diseases. The Secretary appoints non-government individuals as the Committee's voting members. The Tick-Borne Diseases Advisory Committee's voting members include individuals from the scientific community and tick-borne disease voluntary organizations. The Tick-Borne Diseases Advisory Committee includes representatives from the scientific community, tick-borne disease voluntary organizations, health care providers, and patient representatives. The Tick-Borne Diseases Advisory Committee includes a physician experienced in treating tick-borne diseases, 2 patient representatives, and 2 representatives from health departments and organizations. The Tick-Borne Diseases Advisory Committee includes representatives from State and local health departments, national organizations, and ex officio members designated by the Secretary. Members must represent a diversity of scientific perspectives. The Tick-Borne Diseases Advisory Committee includes ex officio members from various Federal agencies overseeing tick-borne disease activities. The Tick-Borne Diseases Advisory Committee includes members from Federal agencies such as the National Institutes of Health, the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality, the Food and Drug Administration, and the Office of the Assistant Secretary for Health. The Secretary may also include additional Federal agencies as deemed appropriate. The Assistant Secretary for Health is designated as the co-chairperson, and appointed members elect a public co-chairperson for a 2-year term. The Tick-Borne Diseases Advisory Committee members are appointed for 4-year terms, with vacancies filled in the same manner as original appointments. Members can serve after their terms expire until replacements are appointed. Members appointed to fill vacancies for unexpired terms will serve for the remainder of that term. They can continue to serve after their terms expire until their successors take office. The Committee must hold public meetings, with at least two meetings a year and additional meetings as needed. Agenda items can be added at the request of members, including the co-chairpersons. The Committee must hold public meetings at least twice a year, with additional meetings as needed. Agenda items can be added at the request of members. Meetings shall be conducted and records maintained as required by law. A report must be submitted annually to the Directors of the CDC and NIH. The Committee, led by the Directors of CDC and NIH, must submit an annual report to the Secretary. The report includes the Committee's functions, member list, activities, recommendations, and any significant issues. The Committee, led by the Directors of CDC and NIH, must submit an annual report to the Secretary. The report includes a list of members and their affiliations, a summary of activities and recommendations from the previous year, and any significant issues. $250,000 is authorized for each fiscal year for the Committee's expenses. Authorized $250,000 annually for fiscal years 2012-2016 for Committee expenses under the Federal Advisory Committee Act. No permanent salaried employee can be a voting member.
